County creates a lower-cost alternative for Southern California Edison customers</h1>                  </div>                <div class=\"trb_article_leadart\"                  ><aside class=\"trb_embed\" data-content-id=\"93076214\" data-content-size=\"leadart\" data-content-type=\"image\" data-content-slug=\"la-1492475708-7agchpx75k-snap-image\" data-content-subtype=\"photo\" data-role=\"sc_item imgsize_ratiosizecontainer\" data-state=\"\">        <div class=\"trb_embed_media\">         <figure data-role=\" delayload  delayload_done imgsize_item\" class=\"trb_embed_imageContainer_figure\"><img itemprop=\"image\" data-baseurl=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58f55ee4/turbine/la-1492475708-7agchpx75k-snap-image\" alt=\"Electricity distribution lines stand at Southern California Edison&apos;s grid control center in Ontario.\" class=\"trb_embed_imageContainer_img\" title=\"Electricity distribution lines stand at Southern California Edison&apos;s grid control center in Ontario.\" data-c-nd=\"2048x1328\" /></figure><div class=\"trb_embed_related\"  data-role=\"lightbox_metadata\" >  <span class=\"trb_embed_related_title\">Electricity distribution lines stand at Southern California Edison's grid control center in Ontario.</span>    <div class=\"trb_embed_related_credit\">Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times</div>    <div class=\"trb_embed_related_caption\">Under a plan by Los Angeles County officials to launch a new utility, Southern California Edison would become more of a distributor of electricity rather than a supplier for many of its customers.</div>    <div class=\"trb_embed_related_credit_and_caption\">Under a plan by Los Angeles County officials to launch a new utility, Southern California Edison would become more of a distributor of electricity rather than a supplier for many of its customers. url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.5.0/benton-gothic-bold.woff') format('woff'),             url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.5.0/benton-gothic-bold.ttf') format('truetype');        font-weight:normal;        font-style:normal;    }@font-face {    font-family: 'Belizio Narrow SemiBold';    src: url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.3.1/belizio-narrow-semibold.eot');    src: url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.3.1/belizio-narrow-semibold.eot?#iefix') format('embedded-opentype'),         url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.3.1/belizio-narrow-semibold.woff') format('woff'),         url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.3.1/belizio-narrow-semibold.ttf') format('truetype');    font-weight:normal;    font-style:normal;}@font-face {    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular';    src: url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.5.0/benton-gothic-regular.eot');    src: url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.5.0/benton-gothic-regular.eot?#iefix') format('embedded-opentype'),         url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.5.0/benton-gothic-regular.woff') format('woff'),         url('https://s3.amazonaws.com/latimes-datadesk-template/fonts/0.5.0/benton-gothic-regular.ttf') format('truetype');    font-weight:normal;    font-style:normal;}.trb_mainContent #story p, .trb_mainContent #story h3, .trb_mainContent #story h2, .trb_mainContent #story ul, .trb_mainContent #story ol {    max-width: 650px;    margin-left: auto;    margin-right: auto;    z-index: 0;}#story p.dropcap:first-letter {    float: left;    font-size: 100px;    line-height: 0.95em;    font-family: Georgia, serif;    margin-right: 0.115em;    color: #000;    text-transform: uppercase;    font-style: normal;}.subscriberholder{    margin: 10px auto;    display: block;    max-width: 450px;    width: 95%;    text-align: center;    border-top: 1px solid #666;    border-bottom: 1px solid #666;}#story .special-promo h3 {    margin-top: 15px;    line-height: 22px;}#story .special-promo h3 a {    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Bold';    color: #333;    font-size: 20px;}.special-promo p#promo {    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular';}.special-promo {    display: block;    padding: .25em 1em 1em 1em;    margin: auto;    max-width: 630px;    background: #f4f4f4;    margin-bottom: 25px;}.trb_mainContent #story p.dateline {    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular', Arial,sans-serif;    font-size: 11px;    line-height: 13px;    text-transform: uppercase;    color: #333;}.trb_mainContent #story p.byline{    margin: 10px auto!important;}.trb_mainContent #story p.dateline{    margin: 10px auto;}.trb_mainContent #story p.note{    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular', Arial, sans-serif;     font-style: italic;    font-size: 14px;}.trb_mainContent #story p.credit, .trb_mainContent #story p.source{    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular', Arial, sans-serif;     font-size: 12px;    line-height: 1.2;    margin: 10px 0;}.medium-banner{    max-width: 650px;    display: block;    width: 100%;    margin: 20px auto 30px auto;}.large-banner{    width: 100%;max-width: 1200px;    display: block;    margin: 20px auto 30px auto;}.mini-banner{    width: 80px;    display: block;    margin: 20px auto 30px auto;}.centered{    text-align: center;}h2.section-title{    margin-top: 18px;     font-size: 32px;    text-align: center;}.trb_mainContent #story h2.benton-title, .trb_mainContent #story h3.benton-title, #story p.benton-title, #preview h2.benton-title{    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Bold', Arial, sans-serif;    font-weight: normal;}#preview h2.benton-title, #preview h3.benton-title, #preview p.benton-title{   font-family: 'Benton Gothic Bold', Arial, sans-serif;   font-weight: normal;}#preview h2.belizio-title, #preview h3.belizio-title, #preview p.belizio-title{   font-family: 'Belizio Narrow SemiBold';   font-weight: normal;}.trb_mainContent #story h2.belizio-title, #preview h2.belizio-title{    font-family: 'Belizio Narrow SemiBold'; }.trb_mainContent #story p.benton-text, #preview p.benton-text{    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular', Arial, sans-serif;    font-weight: normal;}.item-holder{    margin: 0px auto 50px auto;    width: 100%;float: none;display: block;    overflow: hidden;}.small-item{    max-width: 480px;}.medium-item{    max-width: 720px;}.large-item{    max-width: 1000px;}.desktop{    display: block;}.mobile{    display: none;}.text-holder{    clear: both;overflow: hidden;    margin: 60px auto 30px auto;}#story ul.benton-list li{    font-family: 'Benton Gothic Regular';}.introtext{    text-align: center;}.list {    width: 95%;    overflow: hidden;    max-width: 720px;    margin: 10px auto;}.left-panel {    border-right: #d1d3d4 solid 1px;    float: left;    padding-right: 23px;}.hide-border {    border: 0;}.small {    width: calc(50% - 23px);    margin-left: auto;    margin-right: auto;    margin-bottom: 30px;}.right-panel {    float: right;    padding-left: 23px;    border-left: #d1d3d4 solid 1px;    margin-left: -2px;}.double-list-header{    font-family: \"Benton Gothic Bold\", Arial, sans-serif;    margin-bottom: 15px;    font-size: 18px;}body #story figure.full {    width: 100%;    float: none;    clear: both;    max-width: 720px;    margin: 10px auto;}@media (max-width: 767px){    .small {        margin-top: 30px;    }    .desktop{        display: none;    }    .mobile{        display: block;    }    h2.section-title {        font-size: 22px;    }}@media (max-width: 650px){    .right-panel, .left-panel {        border: 0px;        padding-right: 0px;        padding-left: 0px;        margin-bottom: 0px;    }    .small {        width: 100%;        margin-top: 0px;    }}@media (max-width: 480px){}</style><p class=\"dropcap\">Southern California Edison customers in Los Angeles County soon will have an alternative way to get their electricity &mdash; from a new  government-run utility promising lower bills and easier access to clean-energy options.</p><p>The county Board of Supervisors on Tuesday unanimously approved  the public energy program, which they say will help reduce power bills by as much as 5% below what customers pay Edison. Residents and businesses will have the choice to stay with Edison or join the county&rsquo;s utility. </p><p>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s an alternative to Southern California Edison,&rdquo; said Supervisor <a class=\"taxInlineTagLink\" id=\"PEPLT003697\" title=\"Sheila Kuehl\" href=\"/topic/politics-government/government/sheila-kuehl-PEPLT003697-topic.html\">Sheila Kuehl</a>, who helped lead the effort.</p><p>&ldquo;Individual residences, individual businesses, every single person can join,&rdquo; Kuehl said in an interview</p><p>Kuehl said an important feature of the new option is that the public energy program will get much of its power from green sources, and provide it to customers at a lower cost.</p><p>Other than their bill totals, customers are unlikely to notice a difference. Electricity will still be delivered by Edison over its existing power lines. Edison will also continue to read the meters and send the bills.</p><p>But the county utility will buy the electricity from the market or under contract. The county can choose as much green energy as it wants and even build solar projects in the future.</p><p>In the last few years, more communities have been considering such community choice aggregation programs, also known as CCAs. Los Angeles County began studying the concept about two years ago, and its program has the potential to become the state&rsquo;s largest.</p><p>L.A. County&rsquo;s utility plan is part of a broad reshaping of the electric utility industry similar to what happened in telecommunications: a shift from centralized, universal service in which Ma Bell handled all aspects of the business, including maintaining telephone lines, to multiple players that provide many kinds of service on many devices. As technology redefined the role of the phone company, so it is with electric companies.</p><p>For consumers, it means more options. But with more competition from public utilities, Edison and other investor-owned utilities will have to revisit the structure of their business model.</p><p>&ldquo;They will have to change,&rdquo; said Mark Cooper, senior research fellow at the Institute for Energy and the Environment at Vermont Law School. &ldquo;The old system was in place for over 100 years.&rdquo;</p><p>At Tuesday&rsquo;s meeting, Supervisor <a class=\"taxInlineTagLink\" id=\"PEPLT007562\" title=\"Mark Ridley-Thomas\" href=\"/topic/politics-government/government/mark-ridley-thomas-PEPLT007562-topic.html\">Mark Ridley-Thomas</a> called the utility plan &ldquo;a game changer.&rdquo;</p><p>&ldquo;It will allow us to buy and create new sources of green energy while leaving more money in ratepayers&rsquo; wallets,&rdquo; he said.</p><p>Initially, as many as 500,000 residences and 200,000 businesses in unincorporated cities throughout the county will be eligible to join the county-run operation. Incorporated cities such as Long Beach and Torrance require approval by elected officials before their residents can participate.</p><p>The county decision does not affect customers of existing municipal utilities such as the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, Pasadena Water and Power and Burbank Water and Power.</p><p>Southern California Edison said its &ldquo;position is neutral&rdquo; on such power programs.</p><p>For the last five years, state law has forbidden utility companies from publicly criticizing the energy programs.</p><p>But the state&rsquo;s two other investor-owned utilities &mdash; Pacific Gas &amp; Electric Co. and San Diego Gas &amp; Electric Co. &mdash; have raised questions about the efficiency and economics of public energy programs. They have urged more study before wider adoption takes place.</p><div class=\"text-holder medium-holder\"><h2 class=\"section-title benton-title\">How the utility will work</h2><p>Governments from Southern California to Humboldt County in the north have been adopting the public energy alternative as consumers face higher electric bills and the state pushes for clean energy over centralized, fossil-fuel power plants.</p><p>Under the CCA model, cities and counties become responsible for their customers&rsquo; power as well as setting rates and establishing customer programs. </p><p>The L.A. County utility, to be governed by the Los Angeles Community Choice Energy Authority, is expected to start providing electricity next year. Customers who switch to it will be able to choose  whether they want power from solar, wind or another clean energy source. Those decisions by customers will influence how much green energy &mdash; and what kind &mdash; the county invests in.</p><p>The utility will start out buying electricity under contract from generators, but the plan also allows it to develop community-based solar generation, such as installing solar panels on top of warehouses.</p><p>The supervisors approved initial funding of $10 million &mdash; $2 million for administrative costs and $8 million to buy power.</p><p>By the end of three-year phase-in of the program, revenue is expected to reach $1.2 billion, according to the report to the county. But the CCA, as a local government entity, is not allowed to profit from customer rates. </p><p>In 2002, the state passed legislation allowing public energy programs to operate as a way to give electricity customers more choice. Few cities and counties had taken advantage until recently.</p><p>Falling solar power prices are driving the renewed focus on CCAs. Public energy programs can take advantage of the low cost by building large community solar energy systems that not only provide power to their customers but also feed the electric grid.</p><p>Eight CCAs now serve customers in California, with seven more set to launch this year.</p><p>In Southern California, Lancaster established its program in 2015 and Apple Valley in San Bernardino County began its effort April 1.</p><p>Jason Caudle, Lancaster&rsquo;s deputy city manager, said the city turned two years ago to community energy because &ldquo;it allowed the city to take more of an active role to secure green power and more cost-effective power for our customers.&rdquo;</p><p>Now, 94% of the city&rsquo;s possible customer accounts &mdash; about 50,000 customers total &mdash; are part of the public energy program, he said. Power bills have gotten lower, Caudle said, with the program collectively saving $1.9 million, or 4.5% for the average customer.</p><p>Some customers were supportive of Edison and chose to stay with the utility, Caudle said, but &ldquo;we don&rsquo;t have any complaints about being members of the CCA.&rdquo;</p></div><div class=\"special-promo promo\"><h3>    <a href=\"http://ad.latimes.com/land-subscribe-evergreen/footer.html?int=lat_digitaladshouse_4-weeks-99_acquisition-subscriber_ngux_text-link_editorial_______story-footer\">        Support our journalism <i class=\"LATLinkOutArrow\"></i>    </a></h3><p id=\"promo\">    Already a subscriber? Thank you for your support. If you are not, please consider subscribing today. <a href=\"http://ad.latimes.com/land-subscribe-evergreen/footer.html?int=lat_digitaladshouse_4-weeks-99_acquisition-subscriber_ngux_text-link_editorial_______story-footer\">Get full access</a> to our signature journalism for just 99 cents for the first four weeks.</p><div class=\"clear\"></div></div><!--SMALL SVG--><!--<div class=\"item-holder small-item\"><svg id=\"smallsvg\" version=\"1.1\" are paying billions for power they don&#39;t need</a></strong></p><p><strong><a href=\"http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-utility-regulation-20170325-story.html\" target=\"_blank\">Clean energy forces messy changes for utilities and regulators</a></strong></p><p><strong><a href=\"http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-tn-traffic-electricity-20160926-snap-story.html\" additional analysis and comments from Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas</p><p><em>This article was originally published at 2 p.m.</em></p></div><script>\t/* Render tweets */\tvar render_tweets = function data-adloader-adtype=\"cube\" data-adloader-label ></div       >      <div class=\"trb_sc\" data-role=\"sc_information sc_container\" data-sc-c=\"page\" data-sc-url=\"/business/la-fi-county-utility-20170418-htmlstory.html\" data-sc-ti=\"L.A. County creates a lower-cost alternative for Southern California Edison customers\" data-sc-th=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58f6ceb8/turbine/la-fi-county-utility-20170418\" data-sc-desc=\"Los Angeles County officials plan to create a utility that would allow Southern California Edison customers to choose who supplies their electricity and what kind of power -- clean or polluting.\" data-sc-sl=\"la-fi-county-utility-20170418\" data-sc-cont=\"htmlstory\" data-sc-nn=\"Los Angeles Times\" data-sc-contid=\"93076244\"><span class=\"trb_sc_item\" data-role=\"sc_share\" ></div      >  </div>              </div>          </section>        \n  \n  <div class=\" trb_cm\" data-role=\"cm_expandable\">\n    <div class=\"trb_cm_b\" data-role=\"cm_expander\" data-cm-label=\"View comments (28)\" data-cm-t=\"so\"></div>\n    <!-- .trb_cm_b:before{content:'Hide comments'}.trb_cm_so{padding-top:10px;min-height:500px}||<div class=\"trb_cm_so\" .trb_embed_media_next:before,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:before{font-size:40px}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next:hover,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:hover{top:-140px;margin-right:0}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next:before,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:before{padding:12px 0}</script>\n<script type=\"trb/css\" data-css-key=videoscroll>\n</script>\n</body>\n</html>", "title": "L.A. County creates a lower-cost alternative for Southern California Edison customers", "url": "http://www.latimes.com/la-fi-county-utility-20170418-htmlstory.html", "date": "04-18-2017", "source": "latimes", "text": "Southern California Edison customers in Los Angeles County soon will have an alternative way to get their electricity \u2014 from a new government-run utility promising lower bills and easier access to clean-energy options.\n\nThe county Board of Supervisors on Tuesday unanimously approved the public energy program, which they say will help reduce power bills by as much as 5% below what customers pay Edison. Residents and businesses will have the choice to stay with Edison or join the county\u2019s utility.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an alternative to Southern California Edison,\u201d said Supervisor Sheila Kuehl, who helped lead the effort.\n\n\u201cIndividual residences, individual businesses, every single person can join,\u201d Kuehl said in an interview\n\nKuehl said an important feature of the new option is that the public energy program will get much of its power from green sources, and provide it to customers at a lower cost.\n\nOther than their bill totals, customers are unlikely to notice a difference. Electricity will still be delivered by Edison over its existing power lines. Edison will also continue to read the meters and send the bills.\n\nBut the county utility will buy the electricity from the market or under contract. The county can choose as much green energy as it wants and even build solar projects in the future.\n\nIn the last few years, more communities have been considering such community choice aggregation programs, also known as CCAs. Los Angeles County began studying the concept about two years ago, and its program has the potential to become the state\u2019s largest.\n\nL.A. County\u2019s utility plan is part of a broad reshaping of the electric utility industry similar to what happened in telecommunications: a shift from centralized, universal service in which Ma Bell handled all aspects of the business, including maintaining telephone lines, to multiple players that provide many kinds of service on many devices. As technology redefined the role of the phone company, so it is with electric companies.\n\nFor consumers, it means more options. But with more competition from public utilities, Edison and other investor-owned utilities will have to revisit the structure of their business model.\n\n\u201cThey will have to change,\u201d said Mark Cooper, senior research fellow at the Institute for Energy and the Environment at Vermont Law School. \u201cThe old system was in place for over 100 years.\u201d\n\nAt Tuesday\u2019s meeting, Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas called the utility plan \u201ca game changer.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt will allow us to buy and create new sources of green energy while leaving more money in ratepayers\u2019 wallets,\u201d he said.\n\nInitially, as many as 500,000 residences and 200,000 businesses in unincorporated cities throughout the county will be eligible to join the county-run operation. Incorporated cities such as Long Beach and Torrance require approval by elected officials before their residents can participate.\n\nThe county decision does not affect customers of existing municipal utilities such as the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, Pasadena Water and Power and Burbank Water and Power.\n\nSouthern California Edison said its \u201cposition is neutral\u201d on such power programs.\n\nFor the last five years, state law has forbidden utility companies from publicly criticizing the energy programs.\n\nBut the state\u2019s two other investor-owned utilities \u2014 Pacific Gas & Electric Co. and San Diego Gas & Electric Co. \u2014 have raised questions about the efficiency and economics of public energy programs. They have urged more study before wider adoption takes place.\n\nHow the utility will work Governments from Southern California to Humboldt County in the north have been adopting the public energy alternative as consumers face higher electric bills and the state pushes for clean energy over centralized, fossil-fuel power plants. Under the CCA model, cities and counties become responsible for their customers\u2019 power as well as setting rates and establishing customer programs. The L.A. County utility, to be governed by the Los Angeles Community Choice Energy Authority, is expected to start providing electricity next year. Customers who switch to it will be able to choose whether they want power from solar, wind or another clean energy source. Those decisions by customers will influence how much green energy \u2014 and what kind \u2014 the county invests in. The utility will start out buying electricity under contract from generators, but the plan also allows it to develop community-based solar generation, such as installing solar panels on top of warehouses. The supervisors approved initial funding of $10 million \u2014 $2 million for administrative costs and $8 million to buy power. By the end of three-year phase-in of the program, revenue is expected to reach $1.2 billion, according to the report to the county. But the CCA, as a local government entity, is not allowed to profit from customer rates. In 2002, the state passed legislation allowing public energy programs to operate as a way to give electricity customers more choice. Few cities and counties had taken advantage until recently. Falling solar power prices are driving the renewed focus on CCAs. Public energy programs can take advantage of the low cost by building large community solar energy systems that not only provide power to their customers but also feed the electric grid. Eight CCAs now serve customers in California, with seven more set to launch this year. In Southern California, Lancaster established its program in 2015 and Apple Valley in San Bernardino County began its effort April 1. Jason Caudle, Lancaster\u2019s deputy city manager, said the city turned two years ago to community energy because \u201cit allowed the city to take more of an active role to secure green power and more cost-effective power for our customers.\u201d Now, 94% of the city\u2019s possible customer accounts \u2014 about 50,000 customers total \u2014 are part of the public energy program, he said. Power bills have gotten lower, Caudle said, with the program collectively saving $1.9 million, or 4.5% for the average customer. Some customers were supportive of Edison and chose to stay with the utility, Caudle said, but \u201cwe don\u2019t have any complaints about being members of the CCA.\u201d\n\nSupport our journalism Already a subscriber? Thank you for your support. If you are not, please consider subscribing today. Get full access to our signature journalism for just 99 cents for the first four weeks.\n\nivan.penn@latimes.com\n\nALSO\n\nCalifornians are paying billions for power they don't need\n\nClean energy forces messy changes for utilities and regulators\n\nCalifornia considers using high-traffic roads to produce electricity\n\nUPDATES:\n\n6:30 p.m.: This article was updated additional analysis and comments from Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas\n\nThis article was originally published at 2 p.m.", "images": ["http://www.trbimg.com/img-58f6ceb8/turbine/la-fi-county-utility-20170418"], "videos": []}
